article.headline: Texas A&M 63, Texas Tech 55
article.story: COLLEGE STATION, Texas (AP) -- Down by nine with leading scorer Joseph Jones in foul trouble, Texas A&M coach Billy Gillispie knew someone else would have to step up or the Aggies were doomed. Cue skinny and scrappy junior Acie Law, who scored 21 points, including 14 in the second half, to erase a steep halftime deficit and lead Texas A&M to a 63-55 win in the Big 12 Conference opener for both schools. "That's about as much leadership and maturity that anyone could ever show," Gillispie said of Law. "He knew Joe was on the bench, and he took the game over." Texas A&M trailed 34-22 before going on a 15-2 run on the strength of tough defense and hot shooting by Law and Dominique Kirk. "Law really got away from us in the second half," said Texas Tech coach Bob Knight. "They just geared it up a little bit more." Kirk made two 3-pointers in that span and Law's bucket with just under 14 minutes remaining put Texas A&M (11-1, 1-0 Big 12) ahead 37-36. It was the Aggies' first lead since they were up 2-0. "We are not going to quit," Law said. "Things won't go our way all the time. We just continued to fight and got things to go for us, and they made mistakes." Texas A&M scored 13 second half points off nine Red Raiders turnovers. The win breaks a streak of 10 straight losses in conference openers dating back to 1995 for the Aggies. The last time Texas A&M won a league opener was a 90-80 victory, also over Texas Tech, in the old Southwest Conference. The Aggies have won 11 home games in a row and their home record for the last two seasons is 28-3. Jarrius Jackson led Texas Tech with 21 points, and Martin Zeno had 18 points and eight rebounds. Texas Tech (8-7, 0-1 Big 12) led 34-25 at halftime after Zeno and Jackson combined for 27 points. Texas A&M got in an early hole after making just two of its first 15 shots. Jones, who averages 16.6 points a game, finished with just six points and four rebounds. Gillispie said he's looking for a way to help his 6-foot-9 sophomore handle himself when he gets too many fouls early. "Joe's a force," Gillispie said. "He's got to learn to play better without fouling when in foul trouble. I've got to figure out a way to help him do that better." Texas Tech trailed 2-0 before going on a 9-0 run to take a lead that it kept through the first half. Saturday marked the first time the Aggies had trailed by double digits this season and the first time they trailed in the second half at home. Freshman Josh Carter added 13 points for Texas A&M and Lithuanian Antanas Kavaliauskas scored four straight points that extended the Aggies lead midway through the second half. Carter said this win is important for the Aggies to gain confidence. "It's really big," Carter said. "Whenever your best player is on the bench, you hope others step up and they were able to do that. We had to produce from somewhere else." The Red Raiders were hot shooting early, making 61 percent of their first half shots, but struggled late, making just 4-of-16 field goals after halftime. "I think we played as well in the first half as we've played since we played Wake Forest early in the year in New York," Knight said of Tech's double overtime November loss. "We just couldn't sustain it." The opposite was true for Texas A&M, which shot 31 percent in the first half and recovered to shoot 58 percent in the second half. This is the second year that the Aggies have opened the season 11-1.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
